title: Simulating Dice Rolls in R
text:
It is often useful to simulate random events for statistical applications. In this blog post, I will simulate rolling a pair of dice using R and creating some visualizations of the results. For this, I will use Râ€™s built in random number generator.
Step 1: Simulating Dice Rolls

die <- 1:6
roll <- sample(die, 2, replace = TRUE)

Step 2: Repeating the Simulation

n_simulations <- 10000
rolls <- numeric(n_simulations)

for (i in 1:n_simulations) {
  rolls[i] <- sum(sample(die, 2, replace = TRUE))
}

Step 3: Creating Visualizations

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data.frame(rolls), aes(x = rolls)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, color = "black", fill = "white") +
  labs(x = "Sum of Dice Rolls", y = "Frequency")



ggplot(data.frame(rolls), aes(y = rolls)) + 
  geom_boxplot(color = "black", fill = "white") +
  labs(y = "Sum of Dice Rolls")




I successfully simulated rolling a pair of dice using R, and created some visualizations of these results. This technique can be applied to many other random events in statistical applications.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Welcome to my blog!
My name is Rashelle Collins, and I am currently pursuing my Master of Science in Advanced Data Analytics degree with a specialization in Health Data Science from the University of North Texas.
My passion for data analytics and its application in the field of healthcare led me to pursue this program. During my time at UNT, I have been fortunate to learn and develop proficiency in various tools and technologies used in the field of data analytics. These include statistics, probability, Microsoft Excel, SAS Enterprise Miner, Google Cloud Storage, Hadoop Distributed File System, Cloud SQL, Cloud Spanner, Big Query, Looker Studio, RapidMiner, OpenRefine, and R.
